messages.subject: Re: [nihontostudy] The front and back of things
messages.msgSnippet: Agreed on the punches almost always being on the front side (facing the tsuka).  Not much clue from the hitsu-ana on Rich s piece due to the symmetry. Jim ...
messages.messageBody:
Agreed on the punches almost always being on the front side (facing the
tsuka). Not much clue from the hitsu-ana on Rich's piece due to the
symmetry.
Jim
---------------

Punches and other such things are always on the front. Also, there are
differences in the hitsu-ana. I am sure Jim will enlighten us on these.

Gordon

messages.subject: Re: [nihontostudy] The front and back of things

On 2004.1.25, at 07:22 PM, Richard Turner wrote:

> All, recently I got to thinking about distinguishing between the front
> and back of a tsuba with a pattern that is identical on both sides.
> On the image of the Akao tsuba supplied, there is no difference in the
> design regardless of which side we look at it from. The only
> difference is the punch marks that have been added when fitted to a
> sword.
>
> Is this an indication ? were these always facing the tsuka for
> example, or perhaps towards the habaki. Is there anyway to tell front
> form back, or does it not matter.
>
> Cheers
>
> Rich T

messages.subject: The front and back of things
messages.msgSnippet: All, recently I got to thinking about distinguishing between the front and back of a tsuba with a pattern that is identical on both sides. On the image of the
messages.messageBody:
All, recently I got to thinking about distinguishing between the front and back of a tsuba with a pattern that is identical on both sides.
On the image of the Akao tsuba supplied, there is no difference in the design regardless of which side we look at it from. The only difference is the punch marks that have been added when fitted to a sword.

Is this an indication ? were these always facing the tsuka for example, or perhaps towards the habaki. Is there anyway to tell front form back, or does it not matter.

Cheers

Rich T

http://www.image-hosting.net/images/messageboard/retalt/akao1.jpg

[Non-text portions of this message have been removed]
